newsitem.title: USA: Westinghouse CEO sees better dollar/yen balance.
newsitem.headline: Westinghouse CEO sees better dollar/yen balance.

text.p: Westinghouse Electric Corp Chairman Michael Jordan said Tuesday the U.S. government had been too vigorous in its encouragement of a strong dollar, but the U.S.-Japan exchange rate was now coming back into a better balance.
Jordan said there would be discussion of the foreign exchange issue during a Japan-U.S. business conference being held in San Francisco this week.
"It is a concern of American manufacturing industry, but primarily the automotive industry," Jordan, who is chairman of the U.S.-Japan Business Council, told a news conference.
Jordan said he did not claim to know what the "proper" exchange rate was.
"But I do think that the U.S. policy overshot -- in other words the encouragement of the strong dollar by the U.S. government was too vigorous and they waited too long to back off it," he said.
"The exchange rate is coming back into a better balance now," Jordan added. "But I think it has caused a lot of severe dislocations and raised a lot of political issues in the meantime."
Jordan said that while he did not have a firm level in his mind for an appropriate yen-dollar exchange rate, many other members of the U.S. and Japanese delegations did.
"I think this will probably come out better at the end of the meeting when individual sectoral groups will present their discussions," he said.
